Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: REU Site: Water Resources and Quality in the Riviera Maya, Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU site will engage students in research related to water resource management issues in the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico. Science and engineering undergraduate students will work with faculty mentors from Northern Illinois University, Northeastern Illinois University, and the Yucatán Center of Scientific Research on projects related to groundwater recharge, groundwater contamination and public health, and groundwater geophysics. The goals of this REU site include: develop scientific skills in the field and laboratory, install in students a global perspective of water resource issues, develop communication skills in the participants, and develop appreciation for international scientific collaborations. The student projects will be interconnected to better understand the water issues in Yucatán within a cultural and historical context. Because the research project is in Mexico and encompasses a cultural aspect, it is expected that students interested in the region will be attracted to apply. In addition to carrying out research, the participants will produce materials for online platforms to share information with the public, make presentations in Mexico to local officials about the research findings, and publish the results in open access journals.

During an eight-week period, the program will provide a high quality research environment and mentoring to a diverse group of 8 undergraduate students that may not otherwise have the opportunity to be engaged in scientific activities in an international context. The summer experience will consist of: (1) two weeks at Northern Illinois University where participants will define the research they will pursue in the field, participate in ethics training, discuss the relationship between culture and water issues in Yucatán, receive safety and travel information, and virtually meet the team members from Mexico; (2) the next four weeks will be spent in Mexico sampling and collecting field data; the participants will stay in local neighborhoods, away from the tourist areas to gain more in-depth appreciation for the culture. During this period, participants will be working side by side with Mexican scientists and students; and (3) the last two weeks participants will return to Northern Illinois University to continue with data analyses and synthesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This REU site engaged undergraduate students in research related to water resource management in the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico. Science and engineering undergraduate students worked with faculty mentors from Northern Illinois University (NIU), Northeastern Illinois University (NEIU), and the Centro de Investigación Científica de Yucatán (CICY) on projects related to groundwater recharge, groundwater contamination and public health, geochemistry, risk perceptions, organic pollution, and groundwater geophysics. The goals of this REU site included: developing scientific skills in the field and laboratory, installing in students a global perspective of water resource issues, developing communication skills in the participants, and developing appreciation for international scientific collaborations. All of the REU projects were interconnected to better understand water issues in Yucatán within a cultural and historical context.

During an eight-week period, the program provided a high quality research environment and mentoring to a diverse group of 18 undergraduate students that may not otherwise have the opportunity to be engaged in scientific activities in an international context. The summer experience consisted of two weeks at NIU where participants defined their research project, participated in professional development, discussed the relationship between culture and water issues in Yucatán, received safety and travel information, and virtually met the team members from Mexico. The next four weeks were spent in Mexico sampling and collecting field data in cenotes (sinkholes) or other locations around the regions.  During this period, participants worked side-by-side with Mexican scientists and students on a variety of research projects. The last two weeks participants were at NIU for final data analyses and synthesis. In addition to carrying out research, the participants presented research at national scientific conferences.

Over the three-year period, the program also had a positive impact on the participants’ interest in pursuing graduate school or being employed in STEM fields. Some students reported that the program provided motivation and confidence to pursue graduate school.  The program was highly successful in recruiting women and students from community colleges and institutions with limited research opportunities. Sixteen out of the eighteen participants were women. The program has also been highly successful in increasing participation of students from underrepresented groups in research especially Latinos and Black students.
